title: ‘Vaccinated, Recovered or Dead’: Europe Fights Covid Wave — and Itself
content: Europe is again at the center of the pandemic, and amid vaccine resistance and protests, nations are imposing new rules and pressuring people to get inoculated.

title: Chun Doo-hwan, Ex-Military Dictator of South Korea, Dies at 90
content: The country’s most vilified former military dictator, he seized power in a coup and ruled his country with an iron fist for most of the 1980s.

title: How Peng Shuai Went From ‘Chinese Princess’ to Silenced #MeToo Accuser
content: The tennis star won independence while remaining in Beijing’s good graces. But she has been unable to break through China’s resistance to sexual assault allegations.

more_info.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Steven Lee Myers

title: Trying to Blur Memories of the Gulag, Russia Targets a Rights Group
content: Prosecutors are trying to shut down Memorial International, Russia’s most prominent human rights group, as the Kremlin moves to control the historical narrative of the Soviet Union.

des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

title: How Fake News on Facebook Helped Fuel a Border Crisis in Europe
content: Social media worsened a migrant crisis on the border of Belarus and Poland and helped smugglers profit off desperate people trying to reach Europe.

more_info.byline: By Andrew Higgins, Adam Satariano and Jane Arraf
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

title: Limping and Penniless, Iraqis Deported From Belarus Face Bleak Futures
content: Hundreds of desperate Iraqis are being sent home after becoming political pawns in Belarus’s quarrel with its European Union neighbors.

more_info.byline: By Jane Arraf and Sangar Khaleel

title: Critical Witness Testifies at Netanyahu Trial, Reviving a Drifting Case
content: Nir Hefetz, a former spokesman for Benjamin Netanyahu, is a state witness at the former prime minister’s corruption trial, which was once at the heart of a constitutional crisis.

more_info.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner

title: Two of 17 Kidnapped Missionaries in Haiti Are Freed, Group Says
content: After being held hostage for 37 days by a gang, two people with a U.S. Christian aid group have been released in Port-au-Prince and are described as “safe.”

title: A Socialite, a Gardener, a Message in Blood: The Murder That Still Grips France
content: The victim was a socialite. A message in her blood accused the gardener. But a grammatical error raised questions of class and language — and whether he was being framed.

title: As Hopes for Nuclear Deal Fade, Iran Rebuilds and Risks Grow
content: With Iran’s new administration preparing for its first international nuclear negotiations, there are signs that there will be no going back to the 2015 agreement.

more_info.byline: By David E. Sanger, Steven Erlanger, Farnaz Fassihi and Lara Jakes

title: Playwright Is in Exile as Cuba Uses an Old Playbook to Quash Dissent
content: Yunior García, a rising star of the Cuban protest movement, fled to Spain. He is one of a young generation of artists who say they have chosen exile over imprisonment.

title: Angry and Divided, Austrians Argue Over a Lockdown and Vaccine Mandates
content: As a new wave of Covid infections spreads over Europe, resistance to public health measures is growing, and not just in Austria.

title: In Hard Times, Afghan Farmers Are Turning to Opium for Security
content: The war’s intense conclusion and a drought combined to wipe out the famous Afghan pomegranate harvest in Kandahar Province, during a devastating national economic crisis.

more_info.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Taimoor Shah

title: José Antonio Kast, Far-Right Candidate, Leads After First Round of Chile’s Presidential Election
content: The top contenders to lead Chile out of a turbulent era are a leftist 35-year-old former student activist and a 55-year-old far-right former congressman, offering voters a stark choice.

more_info.byline: By Pascale Bonnefoy and Ernesto Londoño

title: 2 Canadian Journalists Arrested at Indigenous Protest Are Freed on Bail
content: Journalist groups denounced the arrest of a photographer and a filmmaker covering an Indigenous pipeline protest in British Columbia.

title: A Long Island emergency room goes dark as a vaccine mandate gets stricter.
content: A free-standing emergency department in Long Beach, operated by Mount Sinai South Nassau, said it had to close temporarily because of a nursing staff shortage.

title: A judge has dismissed criminal charges in Holyoke Soldiers’ Home outbreak.
content: The judge wrote that administrators could not be held legally responsible because the veterans in the case had been exposed before two units at the home were merged.

des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
content: Austria entered a nationwide lockdown.

title: On the Scene: India’s Season of Pollution
content: November is a month of festivals in India. But in the capital, New Delhi, it also brings reminders of the pollution in the city’s air and water.

title: Unrest over vaccine mandates and economic inequality rocks Guadeloupe.
content: Demonstrations started with pickets of at a hospital on the main island,  a French overseas department, and grew violent over the weekend. Protesters burned cars, looted businesses and clashed with riot police.

title: As Germans seek booster shots, supplies of the Pfizer vaccine dwindle.
content: A strong fourth Covid wave has led to a renewed run on vaccines.

title: Kenya will impose widespread restrictions on the unvaccinated starting next month.
content: The move, which will begin Dec. 21, is part of an effort to push more people to get inoculated and curb the spread of the virus.

title: Some Pacific nations will take years to vaccinate their populations, new research predicts.
content: Papua New Guinea will have vaccinated only a third of its adult population by 2026 if it continues at its current rate, according to an Australian think tank.

more_info.byline: By Yan Zhuang and Livia Albeck-Ripka

title: The Politics of Menace
content: Despite a congressman’s censure, Republicans have shown a growing tolerance for violent rhetoric.

title: Australia will allow some visa holders to return in December.
content: The country will allow skilled workers and international students to enter next month, the government announced.

title: Your Monday Briefing
content: The reinstatement of Sudan’s prime minister.

title: Your Monday Briefing
content: Sudan’s military releases the prime minister.

title: Ardeshir Zahedi, Irrepressible Iranian Diplomat, Dies at 93
content: While he enabled business deals worth billions of dollars, he also hosted lavish parties, led conga lines through his embassy and dated Elizabeth Taylor.

title: Covid-19 surge strains Michigan’s hospitals.
content: Staffing shortages and pandemic fatigue add to complications.

title: Vancouver Is Marooned by Flooding and Besieged Again by Climate Change
content: After a summer of deadly heat and uncontrolled wildfires, British Columbia was hit by record rainfalls that forced the evacuation of towns and destroyed highways and rail lines.

more_info.byline: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai

title: As Pandemic Evictions Rise, Spaniards Declare ‘War’ on Wall Street Landlords
content: Protesters in Barcelona are pushing back against foreign investment firms that have bought up thousands of homes over the past decade and are forcing out residents who can’t pay the rent.

more_info.byline: By Nicholas Casey and Roser Toll Pifarré

title: More Asian countries slowly reopen their borders and welcome vaccinated travelers.
content: The easing of restrictions comes as the holiday travel season is about to begin.

title: Israeli Is Killed by Palestinian Near Holiest Site in Jerusalem
content: The shooting, the first attack by a Palestinian since May to result in the death of a Jewish civilian, could deepen tensions within Israel’s fragile governing coalition.

more_info.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Myra Noveck

title: Hair Curlers in Public? That’s Just How They Roll.
content: The young South Korean women who wear them say they are not only functional, but also a sign of shifting ideas about beauty and a reflection of the country’s generational divide.

title: How the U.S. Lost Ground to China in the Contest for Clean Energy
content: Americans failed to safeguard decades of diplomatic and financial investments in Congo, where the world’s largest supply of cobalt is controlled by Chinese companies backed by Beijing.

more_info.byline: By Eric Lipton, Dionne Searcey and Ashley Gilbertson

title: Mining Congo: A Global Power Play
content: The Democratic Republic of Congo has been a critical source of strategic minerals for the United States since at least World War II.

more_info.byline: By Dionne Searcey and Eric Lipton

title: Ousted in Coup, Sudan’s Prime Minister Returns via Military Deal
content: Four weeks after he was detained, Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok struck a deal to end a bloody standoff in the streets. Protesters rejected the move as a “betrayal.”

des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
